European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen spoke with metals industry representatives on Monday and planned a follow-up discussion with the automobile sector. President Trump took to Truth Social on Monday morning to defend his tariff policy in the face of global markets selling off overnight. Wall Street analysts are scrambling to dial back their optimism on US stocks, as Trump’s broad tariff plans send shockwaves through global markets and stir fears of a major economic shakeup. Japan’s PM Shigeru Ishiba is set to speak with President Trump Monday, making a final push to soften a looming 24% tariff. Japan’s Nikkei 225 tumbles into bear market territory. Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has announced plans to head to America in the near future to broach a tariff deal with President Donald Trump. Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One on Sunday, President Trump said sometimes you have to "take medicine" when asked about the market's recent sell-off, according to Reuters. The president added that his policies were not intentionally trying to engineer a market sell-off. The US trade deficit with China reached $295 billion last year. Trump added that he has spoken to leaders in Europe and Asia regarding his tariffs unveiled last week. After US stock market futures plunged on Sunday evening, President Trump posted:. US stock futures plunged Sunday evening, setting up Wall Street for another bruising day on Monday as markets braced for more fallout from President Trump's fast-moving tariff policy. Futures tied to the S&P 500 (ES=F) plummeted around 4%, while those on the tech-heavy Nasdaq (NQ=F) lost 4.3%. Dow Jones Industrial Average futures (YM=F) sank 3.7%. Goldman Sachs' chief China equity strategist Kinger Lau published a cautious take on China's stock market in a new note. One note that caught my attention on Sunday is from EvercoreISI's beverage analyst Robert Ottenstein ahead of Corona maker Constellation Brands (STZ) reporting earnings this coming Friday. Constellation Brands will be in the unenviable position of being the first large company to put finer details on the tariff impact to investors. Trump administration officials are making the rounds on Sunday morning to back the president's position and provide more information as markets prepare to reopen after a historically bad week. Speaking to ABC News, U.S. National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett claimed that "more than" 50 countries had already reached out to the White House to begin trade talks. Speaking to NBC News, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent stated: "I see no reason that we have to price in a recession." Speaking to CBS, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick asserted that the tariffs "are definitely going to stay in place for days and weeks. That is sort of obvious. The president needs to reset global trade.". Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Sunday he hopes U.S. President Donald Trump will ease tariffs imposed on Israel when the two meet in Washington this week. Under a sweeping new tariff policy announced by Trump, Israeli goods face a 17% U.S. tariff. The U.S. is Israel's closest ally and largest single trading partner. title: Stock market today: Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq futures plummet as Trump tariff rout set to continue - (Published 8 hour(s), 27 minute(s) ago)
content: Wall Street is coming off its worst week since the advent of the pandemic, shedding over $5 trillion in value amid Trump's tariff plans.
resumen: On Monday, US stocks recovered early losses in a stunning turnaround. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) erased losses of as much as 3.6%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) surged as much as 1% after dropping as much as 4% in early trading. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) also erased losses of as much as 1,200. The gauges recovered mid-morning despite Trump signaling that he won't change up his trade policy to relieve markets. The S&P 500 was at 5,159.78, +(1.69%) as of 10:20:12 AM EDT. Investors were also weighing Jamie Dimon's belief that new tariffs won't cause a recession, even as the JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO warned on Monday of a hit to US growth and inflation. The Nasdaq Composite entered a bear market on Friday as Wall Street shed over $5 trillion in value to post its worst week since 2020. China has already announced retaliatory tariffs, and the EU is readying countermeasures. The US's new baseline 10% duties on most trading partners went into effect over the weekend, and additional tariffs on so-called "bad actors" are set to be implemented from Wednesday. Markets in Asia and Europe retreated sharply on Monday. Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 (^N225) slid into a bear market, as did the Hang Seng (^HSI) in Hong Kong. Oil prices traded nearly 3% lower, having tumbled about 4% overnight to below $60 per barrel for the first time since 2021. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent rejected the assertion that the tariffs could send the US economy into recession. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the tariffs would "definitely going to stay in place for days and weeks." President Trump appeared to try to calm markets on Monday morning after indicating the Trump administration is speaking with countries following his sweeping tariff announcement last week. Trump wrote on Truth Social: "Countries from all over the World are talking to us," "Tough but fair parameters are being set. Spoke to the Japanese Prime Minister this morning. He is sending a top team to negotiate! They have treated the U.S. very poorly on Trade. They don’t take our cars, but we take MILLIONS of theirs. Likewise Agriculture, and many other “things.” It all has to change, but especially with CHINA!!!" The president made the remarks just a few minutes before the market open. US stocks slid for a third day in a row Monday. The S&P 500 (^GSPC) fell over 3%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite (^IXIC) retreating 4%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) tanked more than 1,200 points. Stocks are continuing to sell off after their worst week since March 2020 as Trump signaled that he won't change up his trade policy to relieve markets. Oil continued to slide on Monday morning. "Magnificent Seven" stocks slid, led by declines in Tesla (TSLA), Nvidia (NVDA), and Apple (AAPL). The European Union prepares its own set of countermeasures following China's retaliatory levies announced last Friday. White House economic advisor Peter Navarro said that tariffs will pay for the biggest tax cut in American history. The 10-year (^TNX) fell as much as 20 basis points since Trump's tariff announcement. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said that Americans who have been saving for years don’t look at the day-to-day fluctuations in the stock market. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick argued that Trump's protectionist agenda will restore domestic manufacturing jobs. "Magnificent Seven" stocks are sliding premarket, led by declines in Tesla (TSLA), Nvidia (NVDA), and Apple (AAPL), after China announced retaliatory tariffs against the US and the European Union prepares its own set of countermeasures. President Trump's tariffs will likely continue to be highly disruptive to the tech trade. Roughly 50% of earnings in the Magnificent 7 come from abroad. The Nikkei 225 entered a bear market on Monday as it closed 7.8% lower, bringing its losses since a December high to 23%. The Hang Seng Index (^HSI) the hardest hit. The Hong Kong gauge closed 13.2% lower to notch its worst daily loss since 1997 and to erase all its gains for 2025 so far. The Hang Seng China Enterprises (^HSCE) index, which lists companies such as Alibaba (BABA, 9988.HK) and BYD (BYDDF, 1211.HK), tumbled 13.7%. The CSI 300 (000300.SS) index in Shanghai sank 7%. In Taiwan, the Taiex pulled back 9.7%. JPMorgan believes the US economy will enter a recession in the back half of 2025 as the impact of President Trump tariffs takes hold in the economy. The firm's chief US economist Michael Feroli sees a two-quarter recession occurring in the back half of 2025 as GDP contracts by 1% in the third quarter of the year and by 0.5% in the fourth quarter. For the full-year 2025, Feroli's team projects GDP will fall by 0.3%. The unemployment rate will go up to 5.3%. The unemployment rate stood at 4.2% in March. Bill Ackman said that, barring Trump calling a "time out" on his tariffs plans, we could be headed for an "economic nuclear winter." The S&P 500 (^GSPC) fell over 10% across Thursday and Friday's trading sessions, while the Nasdaq (^IXIC) entered a bear market. Initial estimates put the combined tariff rate on all US imports well north of 20%. The US' trade deficit with China reached $295 billion last year. Oil prices fell more than 3% on Monday. Bitcoin (BTC-USD) plummeted Sunday, trading around $78,600 per token. Ethereum (ETH-USD) saw an even more intense plunge, down around $1,600 per token. Futures tied to the major indexes were all down around 4% as trading opened Sunday night.

Hours earlier, Germany’s DAX and France’s CAC 40 were down 6.5% and 5.3% respectively, while Asian markets plunged overnight. Black Monday refers to October 19, 1987, when the Dow Jones Industrial Average plummeted by 22.6% in a single trading session. CNBC host and market analyst Jim Cramer warned over the weekend that Trump’s tariffs could lead to a repeat of the 1987 market crash. If you have a pension, stocks and shares ISA, or savings invested in the markets, you're likely to be affected by falling share prices.

title: Donald Trump tariff live updates: 'Over 50 countries have reached out to US for negotiations, says Trump's top economic adviser - (Published Apr 6, 2025)
content: In his most expansive trade action to date, US president Donald Trump's imposed 10% "baseline" tariff on most import ...
resumen:
*   US President Donald Trump imposed a 10% "baseline" tariff on most imported goods, effective Saturday at midnight.
*   The measure was enacted under emergency economic powers, aimed at addressing the country’s trade deficits.
*   The White House cited a lack of reciprocity and foreign tax policies as justification for the tariffs.
*   China responded to a separate 34% tariff set to hit its exports next week by announcing identical tariffs on American goods, effective April 10.
*   Beijing also pledged to file a complaint with the World Trade Organisation and restrict exports of rare earth materials essential to technology and medical devices.
*   White House Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett claimed over 50 countries reached out to Trump for negotiations.
*   Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) will temporarily halt shipments to the United States in April due to the 25% tariff on vehicle imports.
*   Foreign investors withdrew Rs 10,355 crore from India's equity markets following new US tariffs.
*   French Prime Minister Francois Bayrou warned that US President Donald Trump's global trade tariffs could reduce France's GDP by over 0.5%.
*   Zimbabwe's President said he would suspend all tariffs on goods imported from the United States.
*   Elon Musk said he hoped that Europe and the United States would agree to a "zero-tariff situation" which would create a de facto free-trade zone spanning the Atlantic Ocean.
*   J P Morgan projected that the United States will slip into a recession by the end of 2025, attributing the decline largely to President Donald Trump's newly announced reciprocal tariffs.
*   The US stock markets tanked more than 5 per cent on Friday after Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs sparked fear among investors of a global economic recession.
*   US President Donald Trump on Saturday doubled down on his sweeping tariff policies, claiming that China has been hit "much harder" than the United States in the ongoing trade war between the world's two largest economies.
*   Bangladesh's interim leader convened an emergency meeting on Saturday following a warning from textile industry leaders that new US tariffs would deal a "massive blow" to the nation's key garment sector.
*   Indian seafood exports will face significant pressure following the imposition of the US reciprocal tariffs, according to a study by the industry body FICCI.
*   US President Donald Trump is "actively negotiating" tariffs with India, Vietnam and Israel, CNN reported citing officials.
*   The highest tariff hikes announced by US President Donald Trump are aimed mainly at emerging economies, especially in Asia, according to a report by Systematix Research.
*   Thousands of protesters gathered across the United States and beyond to oppose President Donald Trump's policies, particularly his controversial tariffs.
*   Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will head to Washington on Sunday for a meeting with US President Donald Trump, where they will address several key issues, including tariffs and the "Iranian threat."
*   China issued a scathing rebuke to the United States over its tariff hike, accusing Washington of economic bullying and warning of serious consequences for the global trading system.
*   The maker of Jaguar and Land Rover cars is pausing shipments to the U.S. as Britain's struggling auto industry begins to respond to the 25% tax on vehicle imports imposed by President Donald Trump.
*   Taiwan does not plan to impose reciprocal tariffs on imports from the United States, Taiwanese President Lai Ching-te said Sunday, after US President Donald Trump hit the island with a 32 percent levy.
*   UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer declared on Sunday that the global landscape has fundamentally changed, whilst nations prepared for the consequences of newly imposed US tariffs.
*   The Saudi stock exchange was down 6.78 percent on Sunday, official data showed, after sweeping trade tariffs announced by US President Donald Trump sent global markets tumbling.
*   White House Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett defended President Trump's trade policies, claiming over 50 countries reached for negotiations.
*   NSE Managing Director Ashish Kumar Chauhan noted that India is faring better than other countries despite global uncertainty from US tariffs.
*   Vietnam has asked for a last-minute delay to colossal tariffs imposed by Washington as government figures showed on Sunday that its economy grew at a slightly slower pace in the first quarter.
*   Indian metal companies are gearing up for significant expansions in the current fiscal, focusing on growing domestic demand, notwithstanding global trade headwinds.
*   Economy Candy, a well-known family-run candy store in New York City, is feeling the pressure of President Trump's sweeping new tariffs.
*   Vietnam’s economy grew 6.93% year-on-year in Q1 2025, a slight slowdown from 7.55% in Q4 2024, as the country faces major new US tariffs.

*   Prime Minister Keir Starmer and French President Emmanuel Macron agreed on Saturday that a trade war would not benefit anyone, as they discussed the consequences of the sweeping tariffs announced earlier this week by President Donald Trump.
*   Zimbabwe's President said Saturday he would suspend all tariffs on goods imported from the United States, days after US President Donald Trump levied 18 percent tariffs against the southern African nation.
*   Singaporeans should prepare themselves for a period of growing volatility and uncertainty, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong said in a recent address, warning that the relative peace and order the world once enjoyed is unlikely to return soon.

content: Donald Trump has defended his sweeping new tariffs — calling them “medicine” — as stock markets across Asia and the US suffer sharp losses and fears of a global trade war intensify.
resumen:
Donald Trump has defended his sweeping new tariffs — calling them “medicine” — as stock markets across Asia, the UK and the US suffer sharp losses and fears of a global trade war intensify.

The US president warned that other countries would need to pay “a lot of money” to see the levies lifted, despite mounting pressure from European and Asian leaders to soften his stance.

Financial markets reacted swiftly, with Japan’s Nikkei 225 falling nearly 8%, and similar declines seen in Singapore, South Korea and Australia. The FTSE 100 registered a sharp decline on opening, falling 4.86% within five minutes of opening this morning, while US stock futures also pointed sharply lower, with the Nasdaq dropping over 5%.

The new tariffs — a 10% baseline on a broad range of imports and additional “reciprocal” duties of up to 50% — began rolling out this week.

UK goods are now subject to the 10% rate, while goods produced in countries such as Vietnam and Indonesia, where many UK brands manufacture, are facing levies as high as 46%.

Retailers and manufacturers are now facing fresh uncertainty as supply chains and pricing structures come under pressure. KPMG has warned that US tariffs on UK exports could cut GDP growth to 0.8% in 2025 and 2026.

The British Retail Consortium estimates the sector is already grappling with over £4.5bn in extra costs from higher national insurance contributions and the packaging tax.

title: Trade, Tariffs, and Tech - (Published 8 hour(s), 6 minute(s) ago)
content: Tech schools, community colleges, or trade schools could train them. “If you could educate these engineers,” he said, “we could move more manufacturing plants here.” The argument made a strong ...
resumen:
If China invades Taiwan, China would likely be successful, with the biggest unknown variable being time. The U.S. and its allies could repel a Chinese invasion, but at a heavy cost to U.S. military forces and Taiwan. In both cases, China is effectively removed from global supply chains, and Taiwan’s economic output, including chips from TSMC and others, is destroyed.

The U.S. leveraged foreign aid, direct investment, and its consumer market to rebuild Europe and Japan after World War 2, and pegged currencies to the U.S. dollar to do it. This started the cycle of foreign countries exporting to the U.S. and buying U.S. debt with the proceeds. By 1971 this system was about to collapse, leading the U.S. to de-peg from gold and dissolve the Bretton Woods system of currency controls. What changed in the last 25 years was the entrance of China into this system. China had far more capacity than the system could bear. U.S. deficits, both in terms of trade and the federal budget, have exploded in line with Chinese growth. China is the skeleton key to understand so many oddities about the U.S.’s fiscal situation over the last fifteen years in particular, especially how it is that the U.S.’s response to the Great Recession didn’t lead to inflation: Chinese production was deflationary, and their ever-expanding trade surpluses created an ever-expanding market for U.S. debt. This inelastic demand also served to keep the dollar artificially high, in defiance of the theoretical-expected response to long-running trade deficits. This, more than anything else, is what has hollowed out U.S. manufacturing.

Steve Jobs stated that Apple had 700,000 factory workers employed in China, and that was because it needed 30,000 engineers on-site to support those workers. He urged that a way be found to train more American engineers.

The Nixon administration closed the gold window, instituted price controls, and imposed a 10% import tax, actions that effectively ended Bretton Woods. The Nixon Shock was an economic disaster: the country endured a decade of drastic inflation that was only cured with sky-high interest rates and a massive recession.

Trump’s approach, while more theoretically valid than it is being given credit for, is the wrong one. The current economic system is a complex system, built up over decades; one ought to be very wary in remaking complex systems in a top-down manner. There are a lot of other things the Trump administration could be doing, particularly in terms of relieving regulation, ensuring equal opportunity throughout the economy, etc. The China-Taiwan systemic risk is only going to increase. The best way to address the risk is to undo the chip controls and tie China even more tightly into the current system generally, and to Taiwan specifically.

Apple’s benefit from Asia generally and China specifically is articulated in full. Apple would focus its integration chops on getting the product right, and trust contract manufacturers to achieve the flexibility of meeting demand. Manufacturing has changed from being a point of integration with a product to being a horizontal scalable services offering. One benefit of a war over Taiwan is that it would be so terrible for tech companies that there really isn’t much benefit in planning for it. These tariffs are much more complicated. Apple will probably face little choice but to substantially raise prices. Apple’s services business is not subject to tariffs, which is to say it will become even more important to Apple’s bottom line. All of the advertising-based businesses, Meta, Google, and Amazon, will also be negatively impacted. More grist in the wheels of the economy means lower velocity, and lower velocity is bad for tech companies in particular.

title: ‘Looted’ nation: The ultimate guide to decoding Trump’s Liberation Day tariffs - (Published 20 hour(s), 1 minute(s) ago)
content: President Herbert Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, a protectionist trade measure that imposed 25% duty on all imports. Major trading partners Canada and Europe retaliated. What happened next ...
resumen: On April 2, 2025, Donald Trump, speaking from the White House Rose Garden, levied reciprocal tariffs on the US' trading partners. He announced a universal tariff of 10% on all imports, with higher tariffs for countries with a trade surplus with the US. China was hit with a 34% duty, totaling 54% with a previous tariff. Vietnam got 46%; India 26% and the European Union 20%. Even uninhabited islands and territories like Heard and McDonalds Islands, Norfolk Island, Cocos Islands, Christmas Island, and Diego Garcia were affected. Canada, Mexico, Russia, North Korea, Cuba, and Belarus were excluded. These measures take US’ weighted average tariffs to 24%, the highest since 1909. Trump said April 2, 2025, would be remembered as the day American industry was reborn. In 2024, the US trade deficit ran up to $1.2 trillion. Trump hopes to erase the trade deficit and restore American manufacturing. Macabe Keliher argued that tariffs alone cannot rebuild American manufacturing. In the 1950s, the share of manufacturing in US gross domestic product (GDP) was 25%, today it is 10%. According to a Federal Reserve study, when Trump imposed steel tariffs during his first term, the increase in jobs in the steel sector was far less than those lost elsewhere on account of higher prices the tariffs caused. It is expected that the tariffs will, at best, create 1.5 million manufacturing jobs, but the economy will lose 3.5 million jobs if the US heads into a recession because of the tariffs. Moody’s Analytics expects GDP growth to reduce by 2% and the unemployment rate to increase to 7.5% from the current 4.1%. JP Morgan says the odds of a US recession by year-end has risen to 60%. Jerome Powell warned that the tariffs will accelerate inflation and dampen economic growth. EY has said that consumer prices will increase by 1% by year-end, pushing inflation to 4% levels. The impact on low-income households will be $1,000 annually. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) chief Kristalina Georgieva warned that Trump’s tariffs pose a significant threat to the already sluggish global economy. The WTO has said that in 2025 global trade will contract by 1% due to the trade war. India has been slapped with a lower tariff relative to others. For 2025-26, the Reserve Bank of India has estimated GDP growth at 6.7%. Goldman Sachs has lowered the forecast by 20 basis points. Morgan Stanley has pegged a 30 to 60 basis points reduction in growth. The Indian government is negotiating a bilateral trade agreement with the US, aiming to more than double their trade to $500 billion. In the last six months, the S&P 500 has crashed nearly 12%. Investors in the US have lost as much as $9 trillion since Trump took office. In 1930, President Herbert Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act, a protectionist trade measure that imposed a 25% duty on all imports. In 1934, President Franklin Roosevelt had to repeal the tariffs. In 1930, imports accounted for just 3% of US’ GDP, today it is at 14%.

title: Tabletop Games Industry Members React To President Trump Tariffs Plan - (Published 9 hour(s), 38 minute(s) ago)
content: I spoke wih several members from all levels of the tabletop games industry who offered their insight on the immediate, short and long term effects of the Trump tariffs.
resumen:
The article discusses the impact of President Trump's tariffs on the tabletop games industry.

Loren Coleman, CEO of Catalyst Game Labs, stated that the tariffs will hurt the gaming industry at almost every level, leading to price increases, slower sales, potential staff layoffs, and the scaling back or closure of small publishers.

Wolfgang Baur, CEO of Kobold Press, mentioned that the tariffs on imports will increase the cost of printed materials, affecting new releases and preorders. He anticipates potential MSRP increases and the possibility of canceling projects that don't meet financial viability.

Rick Heinz, founder of Storyteller’s Forge, described the tariffs as a "wrecking ball of chaos," potentially increasing production costs by nearly 20% and impacting freelance work.

Gwen Ruelle, co-owner of Runaway Parade Games, expressed concerns about higher prices, fewer sales, and the uncertainty of planning ahead due to manufacturing lead times.

James Lowder, a freelance writer and crowdfunding consultant, believes the tariffs have already caused publishers to scale back schedules and cancel projects, limiting opportunities for creators.

Alex Kammerer, Director of GameHole Con, highlighted the interconnectedness of the global economy and the potential impact on costs, citing the example of aluminum for signage.

Daniel D. Fox, creator of ZWEIHANDER RPG: Reforged Edition, mentioned the exorbitant 54% tariff against landed cost for his print run in China, including books, collector’s editions, cards, GM screens, and dice.

Matt Forbeck, designer of the Marvel Multiverse Role Playing Game, emphasized the difficulty of producing games when costs are unpredictable.

Heather O’Neill, CEO of 9th Level Games, expressed concerns about planning for the future due to tariff uncertainty and consumer buying power.

Samantha Webb, head of brand at Modiphius, stated that they are still assessing the impact of the highest tariff increase of 54% on their board games and plastic miniatures produced in China.

Anne-Marie De Witt, CEO/Co-founder of Fireside Games, predicted that the industry might see simpler, fewer games with fewer deluxe components, higher prices, and a slowdown in purchases of new titles. She also doubts large-scale board game manufacturing will start in the U.S. unless tariffs reach 400%.

title: Trump’s tariffs: What is the impact on Malaysia? - (Published 20 hour(s), 26 minute(s) ago)
content: BARELY three months since returning to the White House, President Donald Trump has imposed tariffs from universal baseline tariffs to country-specific tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico, China and ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico, China, and the European Union, sparking retaliatory tariffs. Tariff action and retaliation have fueled concerns about a trade war, potentially disrupting global supply chains, increasing raw material costs, and pushing up consumer inflation, potentially leading to stagflation or a global recession. China faces further economic headwinds from a 34% tariff. The US economy may face a recession within six to 12 months.

On April 2, 2025, the Trump administration unveiled a reciprocal tariff plan under the International Emergency Economic Power Act of 1977 (IEEPA).

The US Census Bureau data for 2024 showed that the United States has incurred a trade deficit of US$24.8bil with Malaysia (contributing 2.1% of the US total trade deficit), placing Malaysia on the 14th spot in a “Dirty 15” list. Malaysia recorded a trade surplus of RM72.4bil, showing a discrepancy of US$9bil.

Malaysia is a major semiconductor exporter to the US, contributing 13% of global semiconductor testing and packaging. Malaysia’s average Most-Favored-Nation applied tariff rate was 5.6% in 2023. The United States Trade Representative (USTR) has derived that Malaysia is currently applying an average of 47% tariff on US goods. The United States has hit Malaysia with a 24% tariff on imported goods into the United States with effect from April 9, 2025.

Malaysia’s external sector will face challenges due to the tariffs' impact on supply chains, global demand, and business costs. Impacted industries include electrical and electronics (E&E) products (excluding semiconductors), machinery and equipment, optical and scientific equipment, rubber products, furniture products, and palm oil.

In 2024, the United States was Malaysia’s third-largest trading partner, accounting for 11.3% of Malaysia’s total trade. It was Malaysia’s second-largest export destination (13.2% share), and the United States was Malaysia’s third-largest importer (9.2% share). In February 2025, the United States displaced China as Malaysia’s largest export market (14.8% share). More than half of Malaysia’s exports to the United States are electronics and electrical products (54.6%).

The exclusion of semiconductors (RM45.3bil or 22.8% of total exports to the United States) provides relief to Malaysia. Similar exclusions were given to a list of products, including wood products, copper and copper products, energy products, and pharmaceuticals, which collectively recorded RM6bil of exports or 2.8% of total exports to the United States in 2024.

The United States remains a major foreign investor in Malaysia, ranking second in terms of gross foreign direct investment (FDI) in 2024 and fourth largest investor in terms of FDI stock at end-2024. Approved US investment in the manufacturing sector was ranked between second and ninth placing during 2017-2024, with total approved investment ranging between RM1.1bil and RM18.1bil. Overall, the US ranked third in terms of total approved investments with foreign participation in various sectors, recording RM29.7bil or 17.4% of total foreign investment.

The US authorities said that tariffs can be lowered if any trading partner takes significant steps to remedy the non-reciprocal trade arrangements. Trump said he would be open to negotiating with other countries about the duties.

Malaysia will utilize the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement to seek reciprocal trade gains and pursue a Technology Safeguards Agreement with the US.

Malaysia’s small open economy will be affected by the US tariffs and global trade tensions. The direct and indirect impact of tariffs on Malaysia’s export performance depends on the substitutability of the affected products, reconfiguration of supply chains, transshipment, and Malaysian firms’ cost and price competitiveness.

Higher tariffs reduce the competitiveness of Malaysian products in the US market. Global trade tensions are expected to slow down demand and economic growth. Companies’ profit margins could be squeezed.

Lower exports demand would impact employment and income in export-oriented industries. Firms could adopt a cautious approach to capacity expansion. The financial volatility induced by global trade tensions and economic slowdown could negatively impact wealth creation.

The 2025’s GDP growth estimate is revised to 4% from 5% to reflect the impact of tariffs. Domestic demand will continue to anchor growth, supported by fiscal and targeted income measures. Domestic-oriented industries will be relatively insulated from the tariffs shock.

Bank Negara Malaysia will assess the impact of tariffs before making any policy decisions.

Malaysia must continue to move up the value chain, restrategise suppliers and value chains, diversify export products and markets, enhance the investment ecosystem, and attract quality investments. Malaysia must continue to proactively pursue multilateral and bilateral trade pacts.

title: Unease over tariffs in Congress, but will lawmakers take action? - (Published 12 hour(s), 17 minute(s) ago)
content: Members of Congress have been keeping a wary eye on the roiling financial markets that have clobbered Americans’ 401(k) accounts, amid uncertainty over President Donald Trump’s tariffs.
resumen: Members of Congress have been keeping a wary eye on the roiling financial markets amid uncertainty over President Donald Trump's tariffs. Democrats have blasted the president for implementing what they call a “national sales tax” that will penalize consumers and U.S. businesses. Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer said the tariffs amount to “the largest tax hike on families since World War II.” Republican lawmakers, for the most part, have tried to avoid saying much about the tariffs, instead focusing on moving ahead with the president’s legislative agenda and reenacting the Trump tax cuts from his first term. Senate Majority Whip John Barrasso said, referring to the amount that taxes will rise if the 2017 tax cuts aren’t extended by lawmakers, “We need to stop Democrats’ goal of raising taxes by four trillion dollars.” Some Republicans have indicated they are not in lockstep with the president, as the markets ride out a financial roller coaster linked to the tariffs. The Senate has pushed back on tariffs. The Senate has taken related to tariffs was last week’s passage of legislation sponsored by Virginia Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine, which would undo the original tariffs imposed against Canada. Four Republicans, including former GOP Senate leader Mitch McConnell, joined with Democrats to approve the bill. McConnell has been a longtime critic of tariffs. He also opposes tariffs because they would impact “the hardworking Kentuckians who craft 95% of the world’s bourbon” in his home state. McConnell said in a statement, “Make no mistake: goods made in America will be more expensive to manufacture and, ultimately, for consumers to purchase with higher broad-based tariffs.” The Senate passed Kaine’s legislation, it is not likely to go anywhere in the House, where the vast majority of Republicans have vowed to stand with the president and let his trade policy play out. A bipartisan piece of legislation was introduced in the Senate that seeks to reassert congressional authority over tariffs and trade. It is cosponsored by Iowa Republican Sen. Chuck Grassley and Washington state Democratic Sen. Maria Cantwell. The legislation is the first bipartisan measure that would place limits on Trump’s tariff powers. It would require a president to notify Congress within 48 hours of imposing a tariff and the reasons for putting it into place. Tariffs would expire in 60 days, unless Congress approves of them. Cantwell said, “This bill reasserts Congress’s role over trade policy to ensure rules-based trade policies are transparent, consistent, and benefit the American public.” The legislation is modeled after the War Powers Act, which was established in 1973 to limit a president’s ability to take military action without congressional authorization. Grassley’s home state of Iowa relies heavily on agriculture. Cantwell’s state of Washington has extensive exports, including in the aviation industry as well as agriculture. Maryland Democratic Sen. Angela Alsobrooks’ first piece of legislation since she was elected last November relates to tariffs. The Tariff Transparency Act would require the U.S. International Trade Commission to study tariffs and assess how they could affect prices of various sectors, including food, housing and automobiles. Alsobrooks said, “My bill is simply asking for transparency.” Alsobrooks tried to pass her bill by unanimous consent the same day Trump announced his latest round of tariffs. Idaho Republican Sen. Mike Crapo, who chairs the Senate Finance Committee, objected. Alsobrooks said she has met with farms and business owners in Maryland “and they’re concerned, very concerned” about the tariffs. All of the senators from Virginia and Maryland have spoken out against the tariffs on the Senate floor. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz, the Republican chair of the Senate Commerce Committee, warned on his latest podcast on Friday that the tariffs pose “enormous risks.” He said the best-case scenario would be if countries start coming to the Trump administration and seek to cut their tariffs with the U.S. He said if U.S. tariffs and those of other countries remain in place in the coming months, that will drive up inflation and raise prices for Americans. Cruz said, “It will hurt jobs and hurt America.” Cruz also said if the country goes into a recession, the midterm elections in 2026 could be a “bloodbath” for the GOP.

title: ‘The Tsunami Is Coming’: China’s Global Exports Are Just Getting Started - (Published 11 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: A staggering $1.9 trillion in extra industrial lending is fueling a continued flood of exports that could be spread even wider across the world by the Trump tariffs.
resumen:
Over the past four years, state-controlled banks in China lent an extra $1.9 trillion to industrial borrowers. New factories are being built and existing ones are being upgraded with robots and automation. China’s investments and advances in manufacturing are producing a wave of exports.

Katherine Tai, who was the United States Trade Representative for former President Joseph R. Biden Jr., stated that “The tsunami is coming for everyone.”

President Trump announced steep tariffs on Wednesday, which caused stocks in Asia and elsewhere to plunge. From Brazil and Indonesia to Thailand and the European Union, many countries have already moved more quietly to increase tariffs as well.

China’s high savings rate, long work hours, abundance of engineers and software programmers, as well as its legions of electricians, welders, mechanics, construction workers and other skilled tradesmen are factors in its manufacturing success.

China is using more factory robots than the rest of the world combined. Overall installations of new factory equipment have already jumped another 18 percent this year.

When Zeekr, a Chinese electric carmaker, opened a factory four years ago in Ningbo, the facility had 500 robots. Now it has 820, and many more are planned.

China’s exports rose 13.3 percent in 2023 and then another 17.3 percent last year.

Huawei has just opened in Shanghai a research center for 35,000 engineers that has 10 times as much space for offices and labs as Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif.

China has increased its share of global manufacturing to 32 percent and rising, from 6 percent in 2000.

China’s factory output is bigger than the combined manufacturing of the United States, Germany, Japan, South Korea and Britain.

Biden administration officials warned during their final year in office about industrial overcapacity in China and raised some tariffs, notably on electric cars. They left in place tariffs of 7.5 percent to 25 percent that Mr. Trump had imposed on half of China’s exports to the United States in his first term.

Chinese carmakers now face U.S. tariffs as high as 181 percent.

Chinese automakers have continued building factories and have pivoted their export campaigns elsewhere. Their sales have soared in Australia and Southeast Asia, taking market share from Japanese and American brands. In Mexico, Chinese carmakers held just 0.3 percent in 2017; by last year, it was over 20 percent.

E.U. officials last October imposed tariffs of up to 45 percent on electric cars from China.

China has built more petrochemical refinery capacity in the past five years than Europe, Japan and South Korea together have created since World War II.

Robert E. Lighthizer, who was the United States Trade Representative in Mr. Trump’s first term, said that the latest American tariffs “are long overdue medicine — the real root cause is decades of Chinese industrial policy that has created breathtaking overcapacity and global imbalances.”

A housing market crash since 2021 has wiped out much of the savings of the middle class and ruined many wealthy families.

The government is wary of spending on economic stimulus to help consumers. China has offset its housing debacle instead with its export campaign, creating millions of jobs to build, outfit and operate factories.

At the start of this year, the minimum government pension for seniors was just $17 a month.

Professor Li Daokui of Tsinghua University, publicly called in January for raising the minimum monthly pension several fold, to $110.

The budget came out on March 5, it had an increase in monthly pensions — but it was just $3, bringing it to $20 a month.

The same budget included $100 billion for investments, including ports and other infrastructure that help exporters. And there was a new program to upgrade technology used in manufacturing across 20 Chinese cities.

content: This newsletter was originally sent out via email to our Ground Game subscribers on April 7. You can subscribe at any time at apnews.com/newsletters.
resumen:
*   **Tariffs and Clothing:** American industry groups warn that tariffs put on leading exporters by President Donald Trump will increase the cost of clothing for U.S. families. About 97% of clothes and shoes purchased in the U.S. are imported, predominantly from Asia. Trump set tariffs of at least 54% on all Chinese goods, 46% and 49% for Vietnam and Cambodia, and 37% and 32% for Bangladesh and Indonesia. Retailers with big negotiating power, a strong brand name, and limited sourcing in Asia, such as Burlington, Ross Stores Inc., TJX Companies, Ralph Lauren, and Dick’s Sporting Goods, are expected to be winners. Companies with limited negotiating power, limited pricing power, and high product exposure in Asia, including Gap Inc., Urban Outfitters, and American Eagle Outfitters, are expected to face tougher times.
*   **Trump and Netanyahu:** Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet on Monday in the White House. The visit comes as Israel deploys troops in a new security corridor across Gaza. Netanyahu’s office said they would discuss the tariff issue, efforts to return hostages, Israel-Turkey relations, the Iranian threat, and the battle against the International Criminal Court. Israel faces a 17% tariff.
*   **Alabama GOP:** In conservative Alabama, Republicans are cheering for Trump, with some quiet concerns and caveats. Alabama Republican Party Chairman John Wahl led a celebration of Trump. John Merrill, a former secretary of state, noted some concerns and conversations about Trump’s agenda. Terry Martin, a county GOP committeeman in Tallapoosa County, supports the tariffs as leverage but expects prices to increase in the short term.

content: I N ITS SCOPE and severity, the trade war took markets by surprise. On April 3rd, the day after President Donald Trump laid out an unprecedented array of tariffs, the Russell 3000, one of the broadest ...

On April 3rd, the day after President Donald Trump laid out an unprecedented array of tariffs, the Russell 3000 fell by 5%. It then fell by 6% on April 4th, when China announced that it would strike back with a duty of 34% on all American goods. Investors are expecting a severe economic slowdown.

Klarna, Medline and Stubhub have delayed their offerings. The VIX has jumped. JPMorgan Chase now puts the chances of a global recession this year at 60%.

In the past week global cyclicals have underperformed global defensives by eight percentage points—the biggest gap since the beginning of the covid-19 lockdowns in 2020. Our analysis suggests that these price movements are consistent with a mild global recession.

Over the past month the MSCI World has fallen only slightly less than American indices. Investors have lowered their expectations for American corporate earnings this year by 1.5%—the same as for earnings in Europe.

A composite measure of global growth in March rose from its February reading. A “current-activity indicator” produced by Goldman Sachs suggests that global growth is only marginally below potential. Across the OECD, unemployment remains below 5%.

On April 4th statisticians revealed that the economy added 228,000 jobs last month. A weekly index produced by the Dallas branch of the Federal Reserve suggests that the economy is growing by over 2% a year. Goldman’s activity indicator shows America outperforming other rich countries.

title: There’s a Method to Trump’s Tariff Madness - (Published 11 hour(s), 24 minute(s) ago)
content: President Trump’s imposition of high tariffs on friend and foe alike has stunned the world and stumped economists. There is no economic rationale, experts say, for believing these tariffs will usher ...
resumen: President Trump’s imposition of high tariffs has stunned the world and stumped economists. Mr. Trump’s tariffs aren’t really about tariffs; they are the opening gambit in a more ambitious plan to smash the world’s economic and geopolitical order and replace it with something intended to better serve American interests. This plan is often referred to as the Mar-a-Lago Accord. It was apparently devised by Mr. Trump and two of his top economic advisers, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and Stephen Miran, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers. It seeks to improve the United States’ global trading position by using tariffs and other strong-arm tactics to force the world to take a radical step: weakening the dollar via currency agreements. This devaluation, the theory goes, would make U.S. exports more competitive, put economic pressure on China and increase manufacturing in the United States. The Mar-a-Lago Accord echoes the Plaza Accord of 1985, an agreement among the G5 nations to devalue the dollar through a series of coordinated moves. In the decades since, the dollar has remained the world’s reserve currency. What the Trump administration is arguing, in effect, is that the doom scenario is already here: We have an America where manufacturing has declined, economic inequality has spread and a nation overburdened with debt pays for the military protection of its allies. In response, the Mar-a-Lago Accord tries to reverse history. As sketched out in “A User’s Guide to Restructuring the Global Trading System,” a paper published by Mr. Miran in November, the first step is disruption: tariffs that shatter the existing economic order and drive countries to the negotiating table. Once at the negotiating table, countries will be asked to take steps via currency agreements to lower the value of the dollar. Should allies refuse to bend to the tariffs and decide instead to retaliate with levies of their own, they may find the United States withdrawing from defense agreements such as NATO. If unregenerate allies were to significantly increase their military spending in response, the Trump administration would chalk that up as a win. Large numbers of U.S. dollars today are held by China. Lowering their value would amount to financial warfare with China, which the plan endorses. Mr. Miran argues that it is important to “intertwine trade policy with security policy.” This strategy seeks to cut off China from the world economy through punishing tariffs, or a user fee on reserves, which would eventually force transformative change. If everything goes as planned, U.S. exports would be more competitive globally, China would be weakened and more of our allies would be sharing the burdens of military spending. The upshot would be more manufacturing in the United States and a reinvigorated American heartland. Few economists think it will work. The dollar is the world’s reserve currency because it is considered the most reliable place to store assets and to invest. The most valuable asset of the United States is not the dollar but our trustworthiness — our integrity and our values.

title: Trump tariffs live updates: EU prepares countermeasures, markets brace for turmoil - (Published Apr 6, 2025)
content: Yahoo Finance will chronicle the latest news and updates on Trump's tariffs — from the threats to the eventual policy.
resumen: Stock markets in the US and worldwide continued sinking on Monday after the new US tariff policy began collecting duties and global trade tensions continued to rise. President Trump and his top advisers dug in over the weekend, with the president suggesting that equity markets may need to "take medicine" and posting that the new tariffs are "already in effect, and a beautiful thing to behold.". Trump also reiterated that the impetus behind the tariff policy is trade deficits: "I spoke to a lot of leaders... from all over the world. ... I said 'we're not gonna have deficits with your country' ... to me a deficit is a loss. We're gonna have surpluses or at worst we're gonna be breaking even." On Monday morning, Trump wrote: "Oil prices are down, interest rates are down (the slow moving Fed should cut rates!), food prices are down, there is NO INFLATION, and the long time abused USA is bringing in Billions of Dollars a week from the abusing countries on Tariffs that are already in place." A couple of hours later, Trump posted: "The United States has a chance to do something that should have been done DECADES AGO.". On Sunday, administration officials defended President Trump's plans across networks. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick asserted that the tariffs "are definitely going to stay in place for days and weeks." Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said he did not expect a recession spurred by the tariffs, and Hassett insisted that Trump was not purposely trying to tank the stock market after the president reposted a video that claimed he was. On April 2, Trump announced a blanket 10% tariff on all goods coming into the US. He also added new duties on goods from 185 countries, which the president described as the "worst offenders" in terms of perceived unfairness on trade, slated to kick in on April 9. American customs officials began collecting the new 10% tariff on imports from many countries on Saturday morning after the US stock market saw its worst week since 2020. US futures dropped at the open on Sunday evening while bitcoin, seen as a proxy for risk, sold off. Various countries are still deciding how to respond (or not), and companies have begun adjusting to the new reality — largely by raising prices. Some countries responded with new tariffs of their own: Canada announced new duties on certain vehicles imported from the US, and China announced that it will impose countermeasures against the US starting April 10, including a 34% tariff on US goods. The European Union is reportedly preparing an initial set of countermeasures. The tariff rate applied to the 27-nation bloc of EU countries under the policy is 20%, and about 70% of the EU's exports to the US are covered. Trump adviser and Tesla CEO Elon Musk, appearing at an event on Saturday, said that "Europe and the United States should move, ideally, in my view, to a zero-tariff situation." "This is the single biggest trade action of our lifetime," Kelly Ann Shaw, a trade lawyer and former White House trade adviser during Trump's first term, told Reuters. Global markets are plunging amid the new US tariff policy, and world leaders are wondering what President Donald Trump would need in negotiations to relieve the pressure. President Trump said the US is speaking with countries worldwide as global trade reordering sets in. "Countries from all over the World are talking to us," Trump posted on social media. "Tough but fair parameters are being set." The president also stated that Japan is sending a "top team" to negotiate a new trade agreement and called out trade with China as a major sticking point. Markets in Asia retreated sharply on Monday as Japan's benchmark Nikkei 225 (^N225) slid into a bear market, as did the Hang Seng (^HSI) in Hong Kong. The EU has decided to drop bourbon from its retaliatory tariff list against the US. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen spoke with metals industry representatives on Monday and planned a follow-up discussion with the automobile sector. President Trump took to Truth Social on Monday morning to defend his tariff policy in the face of global markets selling off overnight. Wall Street analysts are scrambling to dial back their optimism on US stocks, as Trump’s broad tariff plans send shockwaves through global markets and stir fears of a major economic shakeup. Japan’s PM Shigeru Ishiba is set to speak with President Trump Monday, making a final push to soften a looming 24% tariff. Japan’s Nikkei 225 tumbles into bear market territory, rattled by fears of a deepening trade war. Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has announced plans to head to America in the near future to broach a tariff deal with President Donald Trump. Speaking to reporters aboard Air Force One on Sunday, President Trump said sometimes you have to "take medicine" when asked about the market's recent sell-off, according to Reuters. The president added that his policies were not intentionally trying to engineer a market sell-off. The US trade deficit with China reached $295 billion last year. Trump added that he has spoken to leaders in Europe and Asia regarding his tariffs unveiled last week. After US stock market futures plunged on Sunday evening, President Trump posted:. US stock futures plunged Sunday evening, setting up Wall Street for another bruising day on Monday as markets braced for more fallout from President Trump's fast-moving tariff policy. Futures tied to the S&P 500 (ES=F) plummeted around 4%, while those on the tech-heavy Nasdaq (NQ=F) lost 4.3%. Dow Jones Industrial Average futures (YM=F) sank 3.7%. Goldman Sachs' chief China equity strategist Kinger Lau published a cautious take on China's stock market in a new note. One note that caught my attention on Sunday is from EvercoreISI's beverage analyst Robert Ottenstein ahead of Corona maker Constellation Brands (STZ) reporting earnings this coming Friday. Constellation Brands will be in the unenviable position of being the first large company to put finer details on the tariff impact to investors. Trump administration officials are making the rounds on Sunday morning to back the president's position and provide more information as markets prepare to reopen after a historically bad week. Speaking to ABC News, U.S. National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett claimed that "more than" 50 countries had already reached out to the White House to begin trade talks. Speaking to NBC News, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent stated: "I see no reason that we have to price in a recession." Speaking to CBS, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick asserted that the tariffs "are definitely going to stay in place for days and weeks. That is sort of obvious. The president needs to reset global trade.". Under a sweeping new tariff policy announced by Trump, Israeli goods face a 17% U.S. tariff. title: Boy, Oh Boycott: Can Canada’s ‘Buy Canadian’ Movement Actually Dent the US? - (Published Apr 6, 2025)
content: As Canadians have started boycotting US holidays, the numbers have started to pile up: Statistics Canada said the number of Canadians who visited the US by car in February fell a dramatic 23% to 1.2 ...
resumen:
In response to US President Donald Trump's trade policies, a nationalist "Buy Canadian" movement has gained momentum. Early evidence suggests it could impact certain US states and industries.

Canada imported approximately $350 billion of products from the United States last year, making the US Canada's largest trading partner.

Some Canadian consumers and businesses are redirecting spending away from the United States. There has been a proliferation of apps and extensions advising Canadians on how to avoid American products.

A California-based diaper-maker, Parasol, had a distributor pause a deal to bring its products north of the border. Some Canadian retailers have canceled orders for citrus fruit, and LA-based kombucha-maker GT’s Living Foods has seen its orders halved.

Kentucky, which produces 95% of the world’s bourbon, is facing challenges. Canada's provincial leaders have supported boycotts of US alcohol products. Officials ordered the removal of US spirits from shelves in Ontario, British Columbia, Quebec, and elsewhere. American alcohol accounts for C$965 million ($680 million) in annual sales in Ontario. Canada was the top importer of Kentucky-made spirits before the trade war.

In 2023, Kentucky exported C$289 million ($203 million) in agricultural products to Canada, including C$43 million ($30 million) in whiskey and C$33 million ($23 million) in other spirits.

Brown-Forman, the maker of Jack Daniel’s, Old Forester, and Woodford Reserve, is cutting 12% of its 5,400-strong workforce and selling a barrel-production facility. The company's CEO, Lawson Whiting, warned that a boycott of his state’s liquor products would leave his industry suffering more than others affected by the trade war. Canada makes up roughly 1% of its total sales. Shares in Brown-Forman are down 13.6% this year.

The bourbon industry employs roughly 20,000 people, according to the Kentucky Distillers’ Association.

Border crossings from Canada into the US dropped by 508,000 in February. Michigan saw 108,000 fewer people enter. In 2023, over 700,000 Canadian visitors spent $238 million in Michigan.

Statistics Canada said the number of Canadians who visited the US by car in February fell 23% to 1.2 million year-over-year.

The US Travel Association warned that a 10% reduction in Canadian visitors to the US could result in $2.1 billion in spending losses and 14,000 US job losses.

Canadians are the top foreign buyers of US real estate, representing 13% of the total, with $5.9 billion in assets.

Cross-border flight bookings between the US and Canada have "collapsed." Future bookings were down by over 70% from 2024 in every month through the end of September.

The US Global Jets ETF is down nearly 25% this year. Air Canada is down 37% on the Toronto Stock Exchange this year. US-Canada routes made up 22% of Air Canada’s revenue last year. Cross-border flight bookings were down 10% for the period from April through September.

The Canadian economy shed 33,000 jobs in March.

Stellantis will temporarily furlough 4,500 people at a plant in Windsor, Ontario, for two weeks, with 900 workers in Michigan and Indiana facing similar uncertainty.
